column4: i don't know of a resource, i can tell you roughly (but i might be wrong too) that "VIRT" is what the process has allocated in total, "RES" is what is actually in RAM, "SHR" is what was allocated as shared memory with other programs
thanks.  so doesn't top tell you whether any of a processes' data is swapped out to disk?
not by default i don't think, but there should be an option
ok, will check - thanks

actually, it seems it does, because the manpage actually says that VIRT = SWAP + RES, so the swapped-out portion should simply be VIRT-RES (i thought VIRT also included allocated-but-as-yet-unused pages)
search for "swapped size" in the manpage
ah, ok
hmm, well - just now in my process VIRT is 7843m, and RES is 2.1g - could that mean most of my app is swapped out?  I'm not sure why it would do that when apparently there is 5g free memory
no that doesn't make sense to me, i thought VIRT should always be bigger than RES. i need to look better
well, VIRT is bigger than RES in this case
err... yes of course it is. i read the numbers wrong :>
so yes, it *should* mean that most of your app is swapped out, at least according to the manpage
but i still suspect somehow that VIRT might also include things that aren't really swapped out, but are simply allocated-and-as-of-yet-unused
that doesn't make a lot of sense - why would it swap out over half my app when it has so much free space?
right
is there a better command than top for investigating per-process memory/swap usage?
mind, the manpage doesn't say that, but looking at my own process table, i do suspect that's the case
top should give you all sort of information if you pass it the right parameters - look at the manpage, there's plenty... "ps" should also do
kind of
you can set swappiness to 0, then it will never swap out anything unless it absolutely needs to
i don't know if you can do that per-process
